Bentley Historical Library

titlepage.titleproper:
Finding aid for
Detroit News records.
titlepage.author:
Finding aid created by
Alexa Hagen, in June, 2015.

did.abstract: The Detroit News was a prominent daily newspaper founded by James Edmund Scripps in 1873. The success and expansion of the paper is largely attributed to Scripps' son-in-law, George Gough Booth. The collection contains photographic materials including glass plate negatives, film negatives, and photographic prints of various sizes as well as scrapbooks of newspaper clippings from the Detroit News.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: Donated by The Detroit News (donor no. 11164 ), in September, 2014.

accruals.p: No further additions to the records are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research use. Glass plate and a selection of Film negatives have been digitized and are accessible through links in this Finding Aid. Use of original materials is restricted to staff only.

userestrict.p: Copyright for this collection is shared by the Detroit News and the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Detroit News records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

processinfo.p: [Delete this set of tags if not needed for digital material processing]

bioghist.p: The Detroit News was founded in 1873 by James Edmund Scripps (1835-1906) as an evening newspaper. By 1918, the News published a 36-page daily edition and in 1919 it absorbed the Detroit Tribune. Scripps' son-in-law, George Gough Booth (1864-1949) joined the News in 1888, and contributed to its success and expansion into a new building on Lafayette Boulevard and Fort Street in downtown Detroit. The Detroit News building was built in 1917 and designed by the architect, Albert Kahn (1869-1942). The building was designed to house all of the daily operations of the News including the printing presses required to print the newspaper. The building also had its own hospital, library, barber shop and auto repair shop. The Detroit News' radio station, WWJ was founded in 1920 and is one of America's oldest operating radio broadcasting stations. WWJ's high frequency transmitter, W8XWJ, allowed the Detroit News to become the first newspaper to use an airplane to cover and report the news in 1931. In 1960, the News purchased and closed the Detroit Times and in 1989 entered into a joint operating agreement with the Detroit Free Press.

arrangement.p: The collection includes two primary series: Visual Materials and Scrapbooks.

scopecontent.p: The Detroit News records, 1856-1991 (164.5 linear feet) consist of photographic materials including glass plate negatives, film negatives, and photographic prints of various sizes as well as scrapbooks containing newspaper clippings from the Detroit News. The arrangement of the collection is alphabetical and maintains original order as far as could be discerned. In instances where multiple formats were stored together, they have been rehoused separately for preservation purposes. Researchers are encouraged to review the entire container list of this finding aid to identify corresponding materials of different formats within the collection, which have been indicated.

The researcher will find that a significant portion of the photographic materials depict interior and exterior views of the Detroit News building designed by Albert Kahn and erected in 1917. Additional topics of photographic materials include the radio station, WWJ and various events hosted by the News. Images of the Scripps and Booth families as well as employees of the Detroit News are also present among the collection. The scrapbooks contain newspaper clippings, which present a broad range of subject matter as covered by a daily metropolitan newspaper. All of the glass plate negatives and a selection of film negatives have been digitized and can be viewed by following the links in the container list of this finding aid.
The Visual Materials series (1906-1984, 10 linear feet, 33.4 GB) has been divided into two subseries, Negatives and Photographic Prints.

The Negatives subseries (1906-1984, 9.75 linear feet) contains glass plate and film negatives as well as positive glass transparencies. These materials have been arranged further within the Negatives subseries by format, Glass Plate and Film. These materials range in size from 4 x 5 inches to 11 x 14 inches and are arranged alphabetically by folder headings, which were maintained from their original folders. Film negatives, 1922-1984 (2.75 linear feet) range in size from 4 x 5 inches to 8 x 10 inches and are comprised of both acetate and nitrate film. Content of the film negatives includes images of classroom scenes, crowds in the streets after a Joe Louis victory, a civil rights picket line outside of Woolworth's, and WWJ entertainers in costume. Glass negatives, 1906-1936 (7 linear feet) range in size from 4 x 5 inches to 11 x 14 inches. Content of the glass negatives is less varied than that of the film negatives and includes large runs of images depicting interior and exterior views of the Detroit News building and the previous News building on Shelby Street and Larned Street in downtown Detroit, as well as of the WWJ radio station building. Some of the smaller glass negatives include more editorial content such as images of the annual spelling bee and the Detroit News 50th Anniversary hosted at the Scripps family farm.

scopecontent.p: The Photographic Print subseries (circa 1917- circa 1930s, 0.25 linear feet) contains photographic prints depicting the Detroit News building. All photographic prints are 11 x 14 inches in size. Prints were originally received in the same folder with corresponding glass plate negatives but have been removed and stored separately for preservation purposes. See the container list of this finding aid for corresponding materials.

New Building-Interior-Office of Secretary to Editor-in-Chief-3rd Floor, undated

scopecontent.p: The Scrapbooks series (1856-1991, 154.5 linear feet in 156 boxes) includes books containing newspaper clippings that were collected and maintained by employees of the Detroit News. These scrapbooks are arranged alphabetically by subject. Subjects include local Detroit politicians, George G. Milliken, George Romney, and G. Mennen Williams and other public figures, such as Joe Louis and Ty Cobb. Various corporations are also represented, including Ford Motor Company and Michigan Bell Telephone Company. In addition to public figures and corporations, subjects range from Michigan legislature and election results to the race riots in Detroit. The contents within each book include article clippings arranged alphabetically by topic and each topic is arranged in loosely chronological order. Subjects often span multiple scrapbooks and boxes as detailed in the container list of this finding aid. Researchers interested in local Detroit news as well as regional, national, and global news as covered by the Detroit News may find these materials valuable. Scrapbooks pertaining to Eleanor Roosevelt can be found in the container list under, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, as she is referred to by the newspaper.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p:
The following collections at the Bentley Historical Library may be valuable to researchers interested in the history of the Detroit News and its building. Among these are various issues of Detroit News newspapers and microfilm dating from 1912 to 1951 with some gaps in coverage.
Albert Kahn papers [includes photos and architectural drawings of the Detroit News Building]
Detroit News Lansing Bureau Scrapbooks
Isle Royale papers. (Detroit News)
The Detroit News. (newspapers) [MIRLYN catalog record]
